name: Roll Results
description:
Roll Results

Roll 1d20 + modifier.

  • 16+ (High Hit): Succeed with a bonus.
  • 9-15 (Medium Hit): Succeed, but with a cost or lesser effect.
  • 1-8 (Low Hit): Fail, and face a new complication.

Advantage: Roll twice, take the highest. Disadvantage: Roll twice, take the lowest.

name: Conditions
description:
Conditions

Negative effects that last until removed or their duration expires.

  • Blinded: Disadvantage on sight actions. Attacks against you have advantage.
  • Charmed: Cannot attack the charmer.
  • Confused: Roll d6 on turn: 1-2 do nothing, 3-4 attack nearest, 5-6 act normally.
  • Deafened: Fail actions that require hearing.
  • Frightened: Disadvantage on all actions while source of fear is visible.
  • Immobilized: SPEED is 0. Cannot be moved.
  • Poisoned: Take damage at the start of your turn.
  • Stunned: Cannot take actions or reactions.
  • Taunted: Must attack the creature that taunted you.
  • Weakened: Disadvantage on your next roll.

name: Last Breath
description:
Last Breath

When you reach 0 HP, roll+COS.

  • 16+: Stabilize at 1 HP, but are Weakened.
  • 9-15: Death offers a bargain. Accept to return to life with a cost, or refuse and die.
  • 1-8: You die. Your character's Active Deck is lost.

name: Character Creation & Decks
description:
Character Decks

Create a character by opening one Hero Booster and one Treasure Booster to form your starting deck.

  • Active Deck: Your current character's cards. If your character dies, this deck is lost.
  • Side Deck: All other cards you own. Use these to build a new character after death.

name: Deckbuilding Rules
description:
Deckbuilding Rules

An Active Deck must follow these limits:

  • Unique Cards (Limit 1 of each type): Personality, Culture, Species, Background, Family, Friends, Enemies, Drawback, Destiny.
  • Standard Cards (No limit): Features, Trainings, Items, Hirelings.

name: Crystals & Attunement
description:
Crystals & Attunement

Cards in your deck `provide` crystals to your character's Crystal Pool.

During the Downtime Phase, you may `devote` crystals from your pool to cards that `require` them, unlocking their abilities.

name: Progression & Downtime
description:
Progression & Downtime

After completing an adventure, the party enters a Downtime Phase.

Advancement

Spend 5 XP to purchase a Hero Booster Pack to acquire new cards.

Downtime Activities (Choose One)

  • Work: Gain gold.
  • Recover: Fully restore HP, MP, SP and clear all conditions.
  • Purchase: Spend 100 gold for a Treasure Booster Pack.
  • Deck Management: Swap cards between Active/Side Decks and re-devote crystals.

name: Campaign: World Map & Keys
description:
Campaign Setup

The goal of a campaign is to find a number of Key Tokens scattered across the world to unlock Gate Regions and progress the main story.

Setup Steps

  1. Choose a Campaign Card: This card sets the story, lists the fixed Gate Regions, and specifies the number of Random Region Decks and Key Tokens to use.
  2. Build the World: Draw the specified number of Random Region Decks. Shuffle the Key Tokens face-down and place one on top of each Random Region Deck.
  3. Assemble the Map: Arrange the fixed Gate Regions and the random, key-bearing Region Decks into the grid specified by the Campaign Card. All decks are placed face-down.
  4. Start: Place the party marker on the starting Region Deck and flip its top card (the Region Card) face-up.

name: Campaign: Progression & Gates
description:
Campaign Progression

Your party's goal is to acquire Key Tokens by completing quests in the random regions, then use them to unlock the fixed, story-critical Gate Regions.

Acquiring Key Tokens

When you resolve the final card of a Region Deck that has a Key Token on it, you have completed that region's story and successfully claim that token.

Gate Regions & Unlocking

Gate Region cards have a special 'Unlock' action. To use this action, you must be in that region and spend the required number of Key Tokens. Resolving the 'Unlock' action progresses the campaign's main story, often by adding new, more challenging cards to the Gate Region's deck (from the game box) or revealing the final boss's location.

Winning the Campaign

The final objective is detailed on the Campaign Card, typically involving a final Timed Scene at a fully unlocked Gate Region.

name: The Blighted Woods (Campaign Example)
description:
A creeping blight is corrupting the Greatwood. You must find the three ancient keystones to unlock the path to the forest's heart and confront the source of the corruption.

Ultimate Goal

Defeat the Blightwood Horror in the Corrupted Glade.

Turn Track (1-20)

  • Space 5, 10, 15: Campaign Event.
  • Space 20: The Blight consumes the Greatwood. The Campaign is lost.

Setup

  • Gate Regions (Fixed): 'Oakhaven' (Start), 'The Corrupted Glade' (Final Boss).
  • Random Regions: Draw 4 Random Region Decks from the box.
  • Key Tokens: Place 3 Key Tokens, one on three of the four Random Region Decks.
  • Map Grid: Create a 3x2 grid. Place Oakhaven at the top center, The Corrupted Glade face-down at the bottom center. Place the four Random Region Decks face-down in the remaining spaces.

name: Campaign: World Map & Region Decks
description:
Campaign Setup

The game is played on a world map built from self-contained Region Decks. The Campaign Card provides the ultimate goal and a ticking clock.

Setup Steps

  1. Choose a Campaign Card: This sets the story, win/loss conditions, and the Turn Track.
  2. Build the Region Decks: The Campaign Card will list the regions in play. For each, create a small, face-down deck. The Region Card itself is the top card. Stack its associated Location, Event, NPC, and Quest cards underneath it in the specified order.
  3. Build the World: Lay out the face-down Region Decks in a grid as shown on the Campaign Card.
  4. Starting Position: Place the party marker on the starting Region Deck (e.g., 'Oakhaven'). Flip its top card (the Region Card) face-up.

name: Campaign: The Game Loop & Actions
description:
The Party Turn

The party takes a collective turn, following these phases in order:

  1. Event Phase: Resolve a Campaign Event card if the token on the Turn Track lands on an event space.
  2. Travel Phase: You may move your party marker to an adjacent Region Deck whose top card is face-up.
  3. Action Phase: Collectively take TWO Party Actions.
  4. End Phase: Advance the token on the Campaign Turn Track by one space.

Party Actions

  • Explore New Region: Flip the top card of an adjacent, face-down Region Deck face-up and resolve its text.
  • Engage Current Region: Draw and resolve the next card from the deck of the region you currently occupy. This is how you advance the local quest and find new locations.
  • Downtime/Trade: If the current Region Card has the 'Town' keyword, you may use an action to perform Downtime Activities or Trade.

name: Campaign: Region Decks & Quests
description:
Region Decks & Quests

Each Region Deck is a self-contained adventure. The Engage Current Region action is the key to progressing through its story.

Card Progression

As you draw cards from a Region Deck, they will guide you through a narrative, presenting Quest Cards for objectives, Event Cards for unexpected twists, and NPC Cards for interactions.

Triggering Timed Scenes

When a card from the Region Deck instructs you to begin combat or another encounter, it will always specify which Location Card to use for setup. Since that Location Card is inside the same Region Deck, it is easily found and set up.

Completing a Region

When the final card of a Region Deck is resolved, the party has 'completed' that region. The card will detail any final rewards. You can no longer use the 'Engage' action in that region.

Abandoning a Region

At the start of a turn, the party can vote to abandon their progress in the current region. If they do, discard all remaining cards in that Region Deck, suffer any listed consequences, and advance the Campaign Turn Track by 2 additional spaces.

name: Quest Phase
description:
The Quest Phase

Accepting a Quest Card from a Region begins the Quest Phase, which overrides the normal game loop.

  • Quest Locked: While on a quest, you cannot use the Explore New Region action.
  • Progression: The Quest Card directs you to specific Locations. Travel between them requires a Journey roll. Arriving at a Location begins a Timed Scene (e.g., combat).
  • Completion/Abortion: Completing the quest grants rewards and ends the phase. Aborting it incurs penalties.

description:

description:

These actions focus on controlling the battlefield. Each requires one Action.

name: Physical Combat: Turn & Movement
description:
Turn & Movement

On your turn, you have two Actions (any mix of Ability or Movement) and one Reaction.

  • Movement Action: Move up to your SPEED.
  • Attack of Opportunity (Reaction): Attack an enemy who voluntarily leaves your melee range.
  • Disengage (Action): Move up to half your SPEED without provoking attacks.
  • Forced Movement: Push (away), Pull (toward), Lift (up), Crush (push into a wall for extra damage).

name: Timed Scenes: Setup & The Grid
description:
Setting Up a Timed Scene

A Timed Scene (like combat or a complex trap) begins when a card tells you to. It is always played on a grid. To set it up, follow these steps:

  1. Find the Location Card: The card that started the scene (e.g., a Quest or Region card) will name a specific Location Card. This is your blueprint for the encounter.
  2. Create the Map: The Location Card describes the map's size (e.g., "a 10x10 grid"). Lay out your play area to match these dimensions.
  3. Place Creatures & Terrain: The Location Card's "Setup" section provides a precise list of all creature, NPC, and terrain cards to use. Place their markers on the grid at the specified coordinates (e.g., "Place Orc Grunt at A5," "Place Wall at B2-B5").
  4. Determine the Objective: The card that triggered the scene will state the goal (e.g., "Defeat all enemies," "Survive for 5 rounds").
  5. Begin Combat: Once the grid is set up, the first round begins. Follow the "Initiative & Turn Order" rule to determine who acts first.

name: Physical Combat: Creature AI
description:
Creature AI

Creatures take 2 Actions per turn. Their behavior is determined by their INT score.

  • Low INT (Bestial): Attacks the closest target.
  • Medium INT (Cunning): Targets characters with negative Conditions; uses tactical moves like Shove or Disarm.
  • High INT (Mastermind): Targets the character with the lowest HP; uses cover and powerful abilities.

name: Social Combat: The Grid & Sanity
description:
Social Combat

Engagements of wit and willpower are resolved as a Timed Scene on a grid, identical to physical combat. Positioning, range, and turn order function the same, but the objective is to deplete an opponent's SP (Social Points) using abilities that deal SD (Social Damage).

  • Winning: When an NPC's SP reaches 0, they are defeated (convinced, intimidated, etc.).
  • Losing: If a player's SP reaches 0, they are socially defeated and can no longer influence the scene.

Sanity

Witnessing horrors or learning forbidden truths can drain your SP. An Event or Creature card may call for a Sanity Check (Roll+WIS). Failure costs SP and can inflict conditions like Frightened or Confused.
